pullRequest.title: CB-9901 Update load balancer when instances change
pullRequest.bodyText:
Adds new logic to AwsDownscaleService and AwsUpscaleService. The new logic will
update the load balancer's routing rules to either remove any instances that
are being deleted from the instance groups the load balancer routes traffic to,
or add any new instances in those groups to the load balancer's targets.
Tested with unit tests, and by terminating the Knox gateway node and initiating
a repair to verify the load balancer was correctly updated.

nodes.bodyText:
suggestion: It looks like the String region value here is already present in the AuthenticatedContext ac parameter through String regionName = ac.getCloudContext().getLocation().getRegion().value(); can you get by with just the ac parameter being passed?
I think something similar is going on with the Set<Group>> portToGroupMapping and AwsLoadBalancerScheme type parameters - they're both available in the loadBalancer object in the upscale() method.
I think that would make the method signature cleaner:
cfStackUtil.addLoadBalancerTargets(ac, loadBalancer, instances);
And I think that reflects the "purpose" of each argument:

ac and region are really just here so we can construct clients to integrate with AWS, combine them into 1 to make the signature smaller.
The load balancer we're adding targets to is loadBalancer.
The new targets are held in `instances.

I think in an ideal world the AuthenticatedContext would be provided via DI or some other means since it looks like it's being passed around a lot but actually used in very few places. 🤷

question: It looks like we're subtracting currentInstanceIds from this set of newInstanceIds, is that true? If so, are these actually instanceIdsFromNewTargetGroups?
It's a bit confusing to me to call them new, then remove the ones that aren't actually new.
suggestion: Comments about method signature from above apply here too I think.

question: No longer using this Object resourcesToRemove is very suspicious to me, though I understand if it's necessary to keep the Interface contract intact.
Is that the case?
